This is the second

With an optional subhead

By James Benedict
Published Today

Leads and fonts

Either lead works depending on what type of visual you have. If it is strong, I often recommend starting with lead-img. If it needs to be smaller, use the headline lead.

This is for the first lead-img example

<body> 

<figure class="img-responsive center-block lead-img">
	<img src= ""  alt="">
	<h1> </h1>
	<h2> </h2>
	<h6> </h6>
	<h6 class="date"> </h6>
</figure>

<div id="startchange"></div> <!--this is a empty div used to trigger javascript-->

<nav>...your nav bar code goes in here... </nav>

...followed by the rest of your page </body>

This is for the second lead-headline example. You can replace the center-block part of the code below to change the size of the image. Read the image section of the documentation to figure it out.

<body> 
<nav>...</nav>
<div class="container-fluid"><!-- This needs to be wrapped around your lead, if you are confused read bootstrap's documentation -->
	
	<div class="row intro">
		<div class="col-md-offset-1 col-md-10">
			<h1> </h1>
			<h2> </h2>
			<h6> </h6>
			<h6 class='date'> </h6>

		</div>
		<figure class="img-responsive center-block">
			<img src=" "  alt="">
		</figure>
	</div> <!-- end of intro row -->

...rest of your page 
...</div> <!-- end of container fluid -->
...</body>

This is a dropcap, and the rest of the text is a paragraph. There is also bold and italic. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Fusce ornare egestas mi at elementum. Curabitur consectetur magna congue, tempus ante malesuada, laoreet libero. Pellentesque habitant morbi tristique senectus et netus et malesuada fames ac turpis egestas. Pellentesque tristique efficitur sagittis.

H1 Headline

H2 for subheads and graphic headlines

H3 is for section heads

h4 is up for grabs

H5 for graphics
H6 is used for byline
H6 with the .date class is used for dates in byline

Alignment

The template is here to streamline designing longform responsive articles. It is not a rigid style guide, rules here are meant to be broken. There are three general places to layout your content inline, aside and break. Each of these will be explained later in this section.

Bootstap

This template is developed ontop of bootstrap. If you are unfamilar, read their documentation first. Essentially everything is built on a twelve column grid. You set any element's width by changing the number of columns you want it to span. You can also automatically change this number dependng on the size of the screen. For example col-sm-12 col-md-6 will make an element the full width when the screen at a small size and half width when it is a medium size. There are four sizes, xs, sm, md, lg. Bootstrap defaults to the smallest defined size, so if an element is col-xs-12, then it will be 12 columns at all sizes.

You can also nest columns inside of each other. If I have an element that is always half the screen (6 columns), I can then nest something 12 columns wide inside that. This will make the second element always equal to the width of the first. If the second element had been set to six columns, it would be half the first element or a quarter of the page width.

Each group of columns is wrapped in a row. If I have two 12 column elements in one row they will be stacked ontop of each other. If I have two six column elements they will float left and fill one line. There is no limit on column inside a row. Tracking how things float around each other gets confusing, rows provide a way to organize columns you always want together.

A group of rows is wrapped by the container-fluid. You will likely never have to modify this class because it is mainly used by bootstrap to help calculate the correct size all children elements should be. However, it also keeps things from going full screen. For some alignments below you will have to make sure you open and close the container fluid properly.

Bootstrap's grid has many more options than this, so if you are unfamiliar read the manual. This package will already have bootstrap installed so you can skip the getting started page if you want.

Inline

The main column that this text is in is call inline. It is the equivalent of col-sm-8 col-sm-offset-2 col-md-6 col-md-offset-3 in bootstrap's grid, but takes less time to write. Throughout the rest of the documentation there will be plenty of options showing you inline elements, but the following code will demonstrate where the inline column goes in relation to the row and container-fluid.

<body>
...navigation, lead image, etc...

<div class="container-fluid">
	<div class="row">

		<div class="inline">
			<p>...</p>
			<figure>
				<img src="...">
				<figcaption>...</figcaption>
			</figure>
			...any other content you want in this column goes here			
		</div> <!--  end of inline -->

	</div> <!--  end of row -->
</div> <!--  end of container-fluid -->

</body>

Images

All images should be place inside a figure. Use jpg, gif, or link from a CMS to the image as your image source. The following classes are a layout starting point that can be tweaked by adding an id or changed throughout the article by changing the class. For more layout options place figure inside a column using the bootstrap grid system.

Inline image

All figures nested inside the inline column will display inline by default. 

<div class="inline>
	<figure>
		<img src="..." >
		<figcapti	on>...</figcaption> 
	</figure>
</div >

Inline-left

The inline-left class applied to a figure creates an image 50% the width of the inline column aligned left. If there is nothing to the right of the figure, content lower on the page may wrap up and fill the blank space.

<figure class="inline-left">
	<img src="...">
	<figcaption>...</figcaption>
</figure>

inline-right

The inline-right class applied to a figure creates an image 50% the width of the inline column aligned right. If there is nothing to the left of the figure, content lower on the page may wrap up and fill the blank space.

<figure class="inline-right">
	<img src="...">
	<figcaption>...</figcaption>
</figure>

narrow and centering

The figure class narrow will shrink the figure to 25% width. The class center-block will center align to the element it is nested in.

<figure class="narrow center-block">>
	<img src="...">
	<...>
</div>

Wide

Apply the wide class to a figure to make it 150% width of its container. The figure below is contained in an inline class, so it is 150% the width of the main article.

<figure class="wide">
	<img src="...">
	<figcaption>...</figcaption>
</figure>

Wide-left

Apply the wide-left to a figure to make it 70% of the figure's normal width and aligned left.

<figure class="wide-left">
	<img src="...">
	<figcaption>...</figcaption>
</figure>

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Fusce ornare egestas mi at elementum. Curabitur consectetur magna congue, tempus ante malesuada, laoreet libero. Wide-right

Apply the wide-right to a figure to make it 70% of the figure's normal width and aligned right.

<figure class="wide-right">
	<img src="...">
	<figcaption>...</figcaption>
</figure>

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Fusce ornare egestas mi at elementum. Curabitur consectetur magna congue, tempus ante malesuada, laoreet libero. Nulla bibendum, purus ut sodales pellentesque, erat justo iaculis odio, sit amet pellentesque turpis felis sed elit.

Break

Make an image 100% of the screen width by placing a figure inside a row without a column. If you want the height 100% crop the orginal image or hardcode a height value. If you want the figcaption to allign with the article column place it within an inline div

<div class="row>
	...
</div>

<div class="row">
	<figure>
		<img src="...">
		<div class="inline">
			<figcaption>...</figcaption>
		</div>
	</figure>
</div>

Break-left

Apply the break-left class to a row containing an figure column and a caption column. Size use bootstrap grids.

<div class="row break-left">
	<div class="col-xs-9>
		<figure>
			<img src="...">
		</figure>
	</div>

	<div class="col-xs-9 col-md-3>
		<figcaption>....</figcaption>
	</div>
</div>

Break-right

Apply the break-right class to a row containing an figure column and a caption column. Size using bootstrap grids. Put a figcaption with the classes visible-xs visible-sm to the figure as well as a caption column with the classes hidden-xs and hidden-sm

<div class="row break-left">
	<div class="col-xs-9 col-xs-push-3>
		<figure>
			<img src="...">
			<figcaption class="visible-xs visible-xs">...</figcaption>
		</figure>
	</div>

	<div class="col-sm-3 col-sm-pull-9>
		<figcaption class="hidden-xs hidden-sm>....</figcaption>
	</div>
</div>

Carasoul

Carousels are a bootstrap element. They can be used inline, wide, custom grid structure, but does not work in break. Every caraousel needs a unique id for the wrapping div and controls.

<div id="carousel-example-generic" class="carousel slide" data-ride="carousel">
  <!-- Indicators -->
  <ol class="carousel-indicators">
    <li data-target="#carousel-example-generic" data-slide-to="0" class="active"></li>
    <li data-target="#carousel-example-generic" data-slide-to="1"></li>
    <li data-target="#carousel-example-generic" data-slide-to="2"></li>
  </ol>

  <!-- Wrapper for slides -->
  <div class="carousel-inner" role="listbox">
    <div class="item active">
      <img src="..." alt="...">
      <div class="carousel-caption">
        ...
      </div>
    </div>
    <div class="item">
      <img src="..." alt="...">
      <div class="carousel-caption">
        ...
      </div>
    </div>
    ...
  </div>

  <!-- Controls -->
  <a class="left carousel-control" href="#carousel-example-generic" role="button" data-slide="prev">
    <span class="glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-left" aria-hidden="true"></span>
    <span class="sr-only">Previous</span>
  </a>
  <a class="right carousel-control" href="#carousel-example-generic" role="button" data-slide="next">
    <span class="glyphicon glyphicon-chevron-right" aria-hidden="true"></span>
    <span class="sr-only">Next</span>
  </a>
</div>
...
...

grids

Use the bootstrap grid system for a custom layout. To remove the padding caused by nested columns, wrap the columns in a row grid 

<div class="row grid">
	<div class="col-xs-6">
		<figure>
			<img src="..." alt="">
			<figcaption>...</figcaption> 
		</figure>
	</div>

	<div class="col-xs-6">
		<figure>
			<img src="..." alt="">
			<figcaption>...</figcaption> 
		</figure>
	</div>
</div>

Change the column width to adjust the number of elements per row.

<div class="row grid">        
  <div class="col-xs-4">
    <figure>
      <img src="..." alt="">
    </figure>
  </div>

  <div class="col-xs-4">
    <figure>
      <img src="..." alt="">
    </figure>
  </div>

  <div class="col-xs-4">
    <figure>
      <img src="..." alt="">
    </figure>
  </div>

  <figcaption>Or a single caption</figcaption>
</div>

You can also apply the wide and gridclass to the row

<div class="row wide grid">     
  <div class="col-xs-3">
    <figure>
      <img src="../img/test.jpg" alt="">
    </figure>
  </div>
  <div class="col-xs-3">
    <figure>
      <img src="../img/test2.jpg" alt="">
    </figure>
  </div>

  <div class="col-xs-3">
    <figure>
      <img src="../img/test.jpg" alt="">
    </figure>
  </div>
  <div class="col-xs-3">
    <figure>
      <img src="../img/test2.jpg" alt="">
    </figure>
  </div>

  <figcaption>You can also make it wide</figcaption>
</div>

Or you can escape the inline column entirely and use the full 12 columns.

<div class="inline">
...
</div>

<div class="col-sm-5 col-sm-offset-1">
	<figure>
	  <img src="..." alt="">
	</figure>
</div>

<div class="col-sm-5">
	<figure>
	  <img src="..." alt="">
	</figure>
</div>
